They have been affiliated to the men's team since 2004<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.femalesoccer.net/show_news_article.php?id=3523|title=Chelsea Moving on Up|publisher=FemaleSoccer.net|accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref> and are part of the club's Community Development programme. They play their home games at [[Kingsmeadow]], the home ground of the [[EFL League One]] club [[AFC Wimbledon]]. The club were promoted to the [[FA Women's Premier League National Division|Premier Division]] for the first time in 2005 as [[FA Women's Premier League Southern Division|Southern Division]] champions and won the Surrey County Cup nine times between 2003 and 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.surreyfa.com/previous-winners-and-officials/womens-cup-previous-winners |title=Womens Cup Previous Winners |publisher=surreyfa.com |accessdate=11 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905005953/https://www.surreyfa.com/previous-winners-and-officials/womens-cup-previous-winners |archivedate=5 September 2014 }}</ref> In 2010 Chelsea Ladies were one of the eight founder members of the [[FA Women's Super League]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fcbusiness.co.uk/news/article/newsitem=195/title=eight+teams+successful+in+women%26%23039%3Bs+super+league+bid|title=Eight teams successful in Women's Super League bid|publisher=fcbusiness.co.uk|accessdate=20 February 2011|location=London|date=24 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110125233233/http://fcbusiness.co.uk/news/article/newsitem%3D195/title%3Deight+teams+successful+in+women%26%23039%3Bs+super+league+bid|archivedate=25 January 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2015, Chelsea Ladies won the [[2014–15 FA Women's Cup|FA Women's Cup]] for the first time, beating [[Notts County Ladies F.C.|Notts County Ladies]] at [[Wembley Stadium]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://shekicks.net/news/view/12007 |title=Chelsea lift FA Cup in front of record crowd |publisher=shekicks.net |date=2 August 2015 |accessdate=2 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208081036/http://shekicks.net/news/view/12007 |archivedate=8 December 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and a month later clinched their first [[FA WSL]] title to complete a league and cup double.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34336364|title=Chelsea Ladies: How Women's Super League title was won|publisher=BBC |location=UK |accessdate=30 November 2015 |date=5 October 2015}}</ref> [[John Terry]], former captain of the Chelsea men's team, is the President of Chelsea Women.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/oct/18/john-terry-chelsea-womens-football|title=John Terry digs deep to rescue Chelsea Ladies after funding cuts|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=20 February 2011 |first=Tony |last=Leighton |date=18 October 2009}}</ref>

==Club personnel== Chelsea FC plc is the company which owns Chelsea Football Club. The ultimate parent company of Chelsea FC plc is Fordstam Limited and the ultimate controlling party of Fordstam Limited is [[Roman Abramovich]].<ref name="Club Personnel">{{cite web|title=Club Personnel|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/about-chelsea/about-the-club/club-personnel|publisher=Chelsea FC|date=18 July 2018}}</ref>
On 22 October 2014, Chelsea announced that [[Ron Gourlay]], after ten successful years at the club including five as Chief Executive, is leaving Chelsea to pursue new business opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Club statement|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/10/club-statement.html|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=22 October 2014|date=22 October 2014}}</ref> On 27 October 2014, Chelsea announced that [[Christian Purslow]] is joining the club to run global commercial activities and the club do not expect to announce any other senior appointments in the near future having chairman [[Bruce Buck]] and Director [[Marina Granovskaia]] assumed the executive responsibilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/10/chelsea-statement.html|title=Chelsea Statement|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=27 October 2014|date=27 October 2014}}</ref> [[Guy Laurence]] was appointed as the club's Chief Executive on 11 January 2018, filling the vacancy following the departure of [[Michael Emenalo]].<ref name=GuyLaurence>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2018/01/new-chief-executive-appointed.html|title=New Chief Executive Appointed|publisher=Chelsea Football Club|date=11 January 2018}}</ref>

==Honours== {{Main|List of Chelsea F.C. records and statistics#Honours and achievements}} Upon winning the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League]], Chelsea became the fourth club in history to have won the "[[UEFA club competition records and statistics#List of teams to have won the three main European club competitions|European Treble]]" of [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup/UEFA Champions League]], [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup/UEFA Europa League]], and [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup/UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] after [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] and [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. Chelsea are the first English club to have won all three major UEFA trophies.<ref>{{cite news|date=15 May 2013|title=Chelsea join illustrious trio |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=1947872.html |publisher=UEFA}}</ref>
===National competitions=== ====League titles==== * '''[[List of English football champions|First Division/Premier League]]'''<ref name="premier_league" group="nb">Upon its formation in 1992, the [[Premier League]] became the top tier of [[Football in England|English football]]; the [[Football League First Division|First]] and [[Football League Second Division|Second Divisions]] then became the second and third tiers, respectively. The First Division is now known as the [[Football League Championship]] and the Second Division is now known as [[Football League One]].</ref> : '''Winners (6):''' [[1954–55 Football League#First Division|1954–55]], [[2004–05 FA Premier League|2004–05]], [[2005–06 FA Premier League|2005–06]], [[2009–10 Premier League|2009–10]], [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15]], [[2016–17 Premier League|2016–17]]''' * '''[[List of winners of English Football League Championship and predecessors|Second Division]]'''<ref name="premier_league" group="nb"/> : '''Winners:''' [[1983–84 Football League#Second Division|1983–84]], [[1988–89 Football League#Second Division|1988–89]]'''
====Cups==== [[File:Chelsea 2 Spurs 0 Capital One Cup winners 2015 (16507631718).jpg|thumb|[[Diego Costa]] and [[John Terry]] holding the League Cup after Chelsea's victory in 2015]] * '''[[FA Cup]]''' : '''Winners (8):''' [[1970 FA Cup Final|1969–70]], [[1997 FA Cup Final|1996–97]], [[2000 FA Cup Final|1999–2000]], [[2007 FA Cup Final|2006–07]], [[2009 FA Cup Final|2008–09]], [[2010 FA Cup Final|2009–10]], [[2012 FA Cup Final|2011–12]], [[2018 FA Cup Final|2017–18]]''' * '''[[EFL Cup|Football League Cup]]''' : '''Winners (5):''' [[1965 Football League Cup Final|1964–65]], [[1998 Football League Cup Final|1997–98]], [[2005 Football League Cup Final|2004–05]], [[2007 Football League Cup Final|2006–07]], [[2015 Football League Cup Final|2014–15]] * '''[[FA Community Shield]]'''<ref group="nb">The trophy was known as the Charity Shield until 2002, and as the Community Shield ever since.</ref> : '''Winners (4):''' [[1955 FA Charity Shield|1955]], [[2000 FA Charity Shield|2000]], [[2005 FA Community Shield|2005]], [[2009 FA Community Shield|2009]]''' *'''[[Full Members' Cup]]''' :'''Winners (2):''' [[1985–86 Full Members' Cup|1985-86]], [[1989–90 Full Members' Cup|1989-90]]'''
